story:
The old grandmother Tina arrives in town to attend the wedding of his nephew Alberto with his girlfriend Ileana.
Upon arrival she discovers that she has been stolen of a medallion that her late husband had given her.
He goes to the police station to file a complaint and get the dear object back, but given the length of the investigation, he decides to carry out the search for the thief himself, combining a great deal of mess.
Eventually, by chance, he finds the thief, who lives in the same hotel, also managing to have an entire gang of criminals arrested.
The grandson Alberto can marry the beautiful Ileana and the grandmother Tina will be appointed, by merit, an honorary colonel of the female police.
view1: Tina arrives in town with mixed feelings of joy and nostalgia, focused on her nephew Alberto’s upcoming wedding to Ileana. The happiness of the occasion is quickly interrupted when she realizes the medallion from her late husband is missing. The loss weighs heavily on her, stirring memories and grief. She reports the theft to the police, but the slow pace of the investigation leaves her restless. Refusing to remain passive, Tina takes matters into her own hands, moving through the hotel with determined curiosity and causing confusion along the way. By coincidence rather than careful planning, she uncovers the thief living under the same roof. Her discovery exposes not just one culprit but an entire criminal group. With the criminals arrested, peace is restored: Alberto’s wedding proceeds as planned, and Tina’s unexpected bravery earns her recognition as an honorary colonel of the female police.
view2: An elderly woman named Tina travels into town to attend the marriage of her grandson Alberto and his fiancée Ileana. Soon after arriving, she finds that a valuable medallion once given to her by her deceased husband has been stolen. She formally reports the incident at the police station, but the anticipated length of the inquiry discourages her from waiting. Acting independently, she begins searching for the missing object herself, unintentionally creating disorder during her investigation. Her efforts lead her, by sheer chance, to the responsible individual staying in the same hotel. This encounter results in the arrest of the thief and the exposure of a broader criminal gang. The situation resolved, Alberto and Ileana are free to marry, and Tina is officially honored for her contribution with the title of honorary colonel in the female police.

story:
The nano-plague that poisoned Earth's water supply has reached its 60-year critical mass. The Unlight enemy forced the first exodus to the moon where the outlawed banished population was supposed to die. But now the Unlights have launched from Earth and are amassing on the south-west sector of the darkside of the moon for a massive ice-mining operation.
It is the last Great War and lunar troops are sent into battle for the precious resource. However, one squad is shot down and the five surviving soldiers find themselves stranded. Cut off and behind enemy lines, they start a dangerous journey through snipers and minefields back to their extraction point with only 36 hours of oxygen left. As their numbers dwindle and nerves fray, they make an amazing discovery about the moon that just might save their lives.
view1: After decades of contamination, Earth’s water crisis reaches a breaking point, driving humanity into exile on the moon under pressure from the Unlights. The same enemy now advances from Earth, gathering forces on the moon’s dark side to exploit its ice. As the final war begins, lunar soldiers are deployed to stop them. One unit is destroyed in combat, leaving only five survivors isolated far from safety. With limited oxygen, they move cautiously through hostile terrain filled with snipers and hidden mines. Fear and exhaustion strain their resolve as each loss reduces their chances. In the midst of desperation, the remaining soldiers uncover an unexpected truth about the moon itself—one that offers a narrow hope for survival.
view2: Sixty years after a nano-plague ruins Earth’s water, the Unlights complete their plan by pushing humanity onto the moon. What was meant as a death sentence becomes a new battlefield when the Unlights arrive to mine lunar ice. Declared the last Great War, the conflict sends troops into direct confrontation. During the fighting, a transport is destroyed, stranding five soldiers behind enemy lines. With only thirty-six hours of oxygen, they navigate a deadly route marked by mines and enemy fire toward extraction. Tension escalates as casualties mount and time runs short. Their journey takes an unexpected turn when they uncover a hidden property of the moon that could change their fate.

story: The book follows an international organization named the Ministry for the Future in its mission to act as an advocate for the world's future generations of citizens as if their rights were as valid as the present generation's. Beginning in 2025, the organization, established as a subsidiary body under the Paris Agreement and based in Zurich, is led by protagonist Mary Murphy, a former foreign minister of Ireland and a composite character based on diplomats Mary Robinson, Christiana Figueres, and Laurence Tubiana. Climate change is established as a threat that compromises the safety and prosperity of the future. While the narrative includes chapters of nonfiction history and descriptions of events from the perspectives of other characters and objects, the plot follows Murphy as she seeks to convince central banks of the threats to currency and market stability posed by the effects of climate change. Specifically, a coordinated global round of unconventional quantitative easing through the issuance of a complementary currency, called the carbon coin, to be issued in proportion to the mass of carbon that is mitigated. The monetary concept, called carbon quantitative easing, is based on a specific real-life policy proposal, called a Global Carbon Reward, and an academic paper referred to throughout the book as the "Chen Paper".   In Antarctica, various countries cooperate in a geoengineering project to drill to the bottom of glaciers and pump meltwater up to slow basal sliding while the program incentivizes multiple other simultaneous efforts like carbon farming, sail-driven container ships for cargo and airships for personal transport.
view1: Beginning in 2025, the Ministry for the Future emerges as a voice for generations yet unborn, treating their rights as equal to those living today. Based in Zurich and formed under the Paris Agreement, the organization is guided by Mary Murphy, a seasoned former Irish foreign minister. Climate change frames every action as an existential danger to long-term stability. Through varied narrative styles, the story centers on Murphy’s efforts to persuade central banks that environmental collapse threatens currencies and markets. Her strategy focuses on a new financial tool: carbon quantitative easing, implemented through a carbon coin tied directly to reduced emissions. This economic approach is supported by policy research known as the Chen Paper. Alongside financial reform, nations collaborate on technical solutions, including Antarctic glacier stabilization and broader incentives for sustainable agriculture and transport.
view2: The narrative tracks the work of the Ministry for the Future, an international body created to defend the interests of future citizens. Operating from Zurich after its creation under the Paris Agreement, the organization is led by Mary Murphy, whose background in diplomacy shapes its strategy. Climate change is treated not as an abstract risk but as a direct threat to global security and prosperity. While the book moves through multiple viewpoints and historical interludes, its central arc follows Murphy’s campaign to reshape financial systems. She argues that unchecked climate damage undermines economic stability, proposing carbon quantitative easing through a newly issued carbon coin. Grounded in the Global Carbon Reward concept and the Chen Paper, this plan unfolds alongside cooperative engineering and agricultural initiatives, including glacier intervention in Antarctica and low-carbon transportation systems.

story: Bill Babbitt supported the death penalty, until it came knocking at his door. Bill fondly recalls early life with his brother Manny, but a childhood car accident leaves Manny forever changed. Two tours in Vietnam only compound Manny's mental health issues. After the war, bouts of paranoia leave him living on the streets. Concerned about his brother, Bill and his family invite Manny to come live with them in Sacramento. One day, however, Bill makes a shocking discovery that leaves him with an impossible choice: cover for his brother, or turn him in. Bill explores his attempt to do the “right” thing as familial bonds, mental illness and murder tug a close relationship in conflicting directions.
view1: Bill Babbitt once believed firmly in capital punishment, a belief shaped by distance rather than experience. His memories of growing up with his brother Manny are warm, though marked by the accident that altered Manny’s personality. Military service in Vietnam deepens Manny’s instability, and after returning home, paranoia drives him into homelessness. Wanting to protect what remains of their bond, Bill brings Manny to live with his family in Sacramento. That fragile stability shatters when Bill uncovers evidence of a violent act committed by his brother. Faced with the decision to protect Manny or report him, Bill struggles to reconcile moral responsibility with loyalty. His attempt to choose what he sees as right exposes the painful intersection of love, illness, and irreversible consequence.
view2: The story traces Bill Babbitt’s shift in perspective after a lifetime of supporting the death penalty. His childhood with Manny was close, but a serious car accident changed Manny in lasting ways. War service in Vietnam worsened those changes, and upon returning, Manny drifted into paranoia and life on the streets. Hoping to help, Bill welcomes his brother into his Sacramento home. The situation escalates when Bill discovers Manny’s involvement in a killing, forcing an agonizing decision. Torn between shielding his brother and obeying the law, Bill confronts the cost of his values. As mental illness, family loyalty, and violence collide, his choice permanently alters their relationship.
